verses.verse: (Dimensions and Design of the Temple Area) So he measured the temple, one (Ezek. 40:47) hundred cubits long; and the separating courtyard with the building and its walls was one hundred cubits long;
also the width of the eastern face of the temple, including the separating courtyard, was one hundred cubits.

He measured the length of the building behind it, facing the separating courtyard, with its (Ezek. 42:3, 5) galleries on the one side and on the other side, one hundred cubits, as well as the inner temple and the porches of the court,

their doorposts and (1 Kin. 6:4; Ezek. 40:16, 25) the beveled window frames. And the galleries all around their three stories opposite the threshold were paneled with (1 Kin. 6:15) wood from the ground to the windows—the windows were covered—
from the space above the door, even to the inner room, as well as outside, and on every wall all around, inside and outside, by measure.
And it was made (1 Kin. 6:29; 2 Chr. 3:7) with cherubim and (2 Chr. 3:5; Ezek. 40:16) palm trees, a palm tree between cherub and cherub. Each cherub had two faces,
(Ezek. 1:10; 10:14) so that the face of a man was toward a palm tree on one side, and the face of a young lion toward a palm tree on the other side; thus it was made throughout the temple all around.
From the floor to the space above the door, and on the wall of the sanctuary, cherubim and palm trees were carved.
The (1 Kin. 6:33; Ezek. 40:9, 14, 16; 41:1) doorposts of the temple were square, as was the front of the sanctuary; their appearance was similar.

(Ex. 30:1-3; 1 Kin. 6:20; Rev. 8:3) The altar was of wood, three cubits high, and its length two cubits. Its corners, its length, and its sides were of wood; and he said to me, “This is (Ex. 25:23, 30; Lev. 24:6; Ezek. 23:41; 44:16; Mal. 1:7, 12) the table that is (Ex. 30:8) before the LORD.”
(1 Kin. 6:31-35) The temple and the sanctuary had two doors.
The doors had two (1 Kin. 6:34) panels apiece, two folding panels: two panels for one door and two panels for the other door.
Cherubim and palm trees were carved on the doors of the temple just as they were carved on the walls. A wooden canopy was on the front of the vestibule outside.
There were (Ezek. 40:16) beveled window frames and palm trees on one side and on the other, on the sides of the vestibule—also on the side chambers of the temple and on the canopies.

(The Chambers for the Priests) Then he (Ezek. 41:1) brought me out into the outer court, by the way toward the (Ezek. 40:20) north; and he brought me into (Ezek. 41:12, 15) the chamber which was opposite the separating courtyard, and which was opposite the building toward the north.
Facing the length, which was one hundred cubits (the width was fifty cubits), was the north door.
Opposite the inner court of twenty cubits, and opposite the (Ezek. 40:17) pavement of the outer court, was (Ezek. 41:15, 16; 42:5) gallery against gallery in three stories.
In front of the chambers, toward the inside, was a walk ten cubits wide, at a distance of one cubit; and their doors faced north.
Now the upper chambers were shorter, because the galleries took away space from them more than from the lower and middle stories of the building.
For they were in three stories and did not have pillars like the pillars of the courts; therefore the upper level was shortened more than the lower and middle levels from the ground up.
